message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about how animals regulate their body temperature and hydration. In hot environments, animals are more likely to become thirsty more easily. Option (A) is inaccurate because animals do not get sun tans under their fur, as fur provides some protection from the sun's rays. Option (B) is unlikely as animals need to find shade and rest to avoid overheating in hot environments. Option (D) is a hyperbole and does not accurately describe the effects of heat on animals.

This question requires basic knowledge about how the body reacts to heat and physical activity. When animals are active in hot environments, they tend to become thirsty more easily. This is because they sweat and pant in order to regulate their body temperature, which leads to fluid loss. Option (A) is incorrect because animals do not develop sun tans under their fur. Option (B) is unlikely because running requires a lot of energy and it would be difficult for an animal to sleep while running. Option (D) is a gruesome and incorrect option, as animals do not become "fried and baked alive" in hot environments.

Option (A) is incorrect because animals do not get a sun tan under their fur. Option (B) is unrealistic and not related to animal behavior in hot environments. Option (D) is a sensationalized and extreme response that does not accurately reflect what happens to animals in hot environments.
